Hydrotalcite-calcined derivatives doped by zinc: A nucleophile-modified multifunctional catalyst for synthesis of propylene carbonate by cycloaddition Shao-Rui Zhang Methodology Software Validation Formal analysis Investigation Data curation Project administration Writing – original draft Visualization Conceptualization Yue Fu Software Validation Formal analysis Investigation Data curation Project administration Writing – review & editing Hui Lv Resources Project administration Writing – review & editing Supervision ⁎ Gui-Ping Cao Conceptualization Supervision Resources Project administration Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition ⁎ UNILAB, State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering, School of Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai 200237, PR China UNILAB, State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering, School of Chemical Engineering East China University of Science and Technology Shanghai 200237 PR China UNILAB, State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering, School of Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai 200237, P.R. China ⁎ Corresponding authors. The composition of hydrotalcite-calcined derivatives doped by Zinc was optimized by uniform design. This derivatives further modified by KI nucleophile promoted the catalytic performance in terms of activity, selectivity and stability. N,N-dimethylformamide was proved to be the best solvent for the cycloaddition through molecular simulation. The results of characterization showed that KI-modified derivatives had hydrotalcite phase and ZnO phase, and the elements with catalytic activity were uniformly dispersed. The specific surface area of the derivatives was greatly increased after proper calcination, and it's positively correlated with the cycloaddition activity.The derivatives had acidic-basic properties, and the catalytic mechanism was proposed accordingly. Keywords Cycloaddition Uniform design Molecular simulation Hydrotalcites Nucleophiles Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction With the massive exploitation and utilization of fossil energy, the emission of CO2 is increasing, leading to the deterioration of the earth's environment [1]. How to effectively reduce the emission of CO2 while developing the economy has become an major issue to be solved urgently in the current academic and business circles. CO2 is an abundant C1 resource [2]. Synthesis of propylene carbonate (PC) from CO2 is an effective way to rationally utilize CO2 and reduce carbon emissions. PC has a wide range of applications in organic synthesis, gas separation, and metal extraction, such as the synthesis of dimethyl carbonate [3], CO2 and H2S absorbent [4], and metal extraction agent [5]. PC, as a polar aprotic solvent with high dipole moment and high dielectric constant [6], is particularly suitable for anhydrous electrochemical applications, such as excellent dielectric materials for capacitors or high-energy batteries [7]. Applying PC to the new energy field can realize the combination of CO2 utilization and new energy development. The early methods of PC synthesis based on 1,2-propanediol include phosgene method [8], transesterification method [9], and CO2 method [10]. “Phosgene method” requires highly toxic phosgene, which puts forward high requirements for Environment Health Safety. The raw material dimethyl carbonate used in “transesterification method” is expensive. “CO2 method” produces by-product H2O, which increases the energy consumption for separation. Therefore, the pathway to synthesize PC focuses on the cycloaddition of propylene oxide (PO) and CO2 [9,11] (Scheme 1 ). The atom utilization rate of this reaction is 100%. However, CO2 is chemically inactive [12]. In order to promote the yield of PC from the cycloaddition of PO and CO2, a catalyst with high activity for both PO ring opening and CO2 activation is required. In the past few decades, many related catalysts have been reported, including alkali metal salts [13,14], organic ammonium salts [15,16], organometallic complexes [17,18], ionic liquids [19,20], etc., but these are all homogeneous catalysts with high separation energy consumption, low durability, and low recycling performance. In recent years, heterogeneous catalysts are studied, such as metal oxides [21,22], molecular sieves [23,24], porous organic polymers [25,26], metal-organic frameworks [27,28], etc. Although these heterogeneous catalysts can solve the problem of separation and reutilization, their catalytic activity are lower than those of homogeneous catalysts [29]. A common method to combine the high activity of homogeneous catalysts with the reusability of heterogeneous catalysts is to support the homogeneous catalyst on the surface of a suitable support, which not only solves the problem of efficient separation and reusability, but also has the technical advantages in device design and operation. Hydrotalcite (HT) is a layered hydroxide with exchangeable metal cations and interlayer anions, which has been widely used in the field of catalysis [21,30,31]. As a typical HT, MgAl HT can be calcined to obtain a high specific surface area, and the calcined compound exists in the form of metal oxides [32]. The HT-derived composite oxides have the memory effect [30]: the layered structure of original HT can be restored after contacting with a specific aqueous solution. Therefore, MgAl HT can be used as an effective support, and active elements can be introduced into the HT by the exchangeability of anions and cations. Many researches have shown that the zinc can greatly improve the catalytic performance of the cycloaddition [33,34]. For example, Chen et al. [35] introduced zinc into the porous porphyrin framework, and the PO conversion increased by >3.5 times under the same reaction conditions. In addition, nucleophiles (halide ions such as Cl−, Br−, I−, etc.) have been reported to promote PO ring-opening activation [33,35], enhancing the catalytic activity. Therefore, in this work, zinc was introduced into MgAl HT by co-precipitation method to synthesize trimetallic HT, and trimetallic HT-derived oxides were obtained after calcination. Halide ion (nucleophile) was loaded into the oxides by the anion exchangeability and the memory effect after calcination at appropriate temperature. A series of exploratory works were carried out in combination with the uniform design and molecular simulation, in order to solve the key scientific problems such as the structure design, synthesis and structure-activity relationship of supported catalysts with high activity, selectivity and stability for the cycloaddition of PO and CO2. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts The experimental materials are presented in the Supplementary material. All medicines are used directly without treatment. Trimetallic HT was prepared by co-precipitation method [31,36]. The trimetallic composite oxide was prepared under the conditions of Mg and Al molar ratio q 1 = n(Mg)/n(Al) = 1.31, Zn and Al molar ratio q 2 = n(Zn)/n(Al) = 1.87, and the calcination temperature is 450 °C, which was denoted as CHT-1.31-1.87-450, and the corresponding uncalcined HT was denoted as HT-1.31-1.87. The trimetallic composite oxide loaded with 5 wt% KI (calculated as composite oxide) was denoted as 5% KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450. Taking 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450 as an example to illustrate the preparation process: 100 mL of Cs2CO3 aqueous solution (1 mol/L) was added to a 500 mL three-necked flask and stirred at 60 °C. MgSO4·7H2O (0.0376 mol), Al2(SO4)3·18H2O (0.0144 mol), and ZnSO4·7H2O (0.0538 mol) were dissolved in 100 mL of deionized water, and then added to the flask at 2 mL/min. The suspension in the flask was adjusted to pH = 10 with CsOH aqueous solution (10 mol/L), and stirred at 60 °C for 1 h. The suspension was filtered and washed several times until the filtrate was neutral. The filter cake was transferred to a crucible and dried at 80 °C for 24 h under vacuum (0.01 atm) to obtain trimetallic HT (HT-1.31-1.87). After HT-1.31-1.87 was ground into powder, it was calcined at 450 °C (heating rate 5 °C/min) in a muffle furnace for 6 h to prepare trimetallic HT-calcined derivatives (CHT-1.31-1.87-450). CHT-1.31-1.87-450 (3 g) was added to an aqueous solution containing KI (0.2 g), and sonicated for 10 min. After immersion at room temperature for 20 h, it was dried at 60 °C. The samples were ground and calcined using the same procedure as above to prepare KI-loaded trimetallic composite oxides (5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450). The details of the characterization methods of TG-DSC, XRD, SEM-EDS, STEM-EDS, FT-IR, BET, Py-FTIR, NH3-TPD, and CO2-TPD for all of the samples are presented in the Supplementary material. 2.2 Uniform design Uniform design is an optimal experimental design method jointly proposed by Fang and Wang in 1978. In this work, a 2-factor, 10-level uniform design model was used to optimize the effect of the metal ratio (q 1, q 2) of the trimetallic HT-derived oxide on the yield of PC (Y PC, %).Taking q 1∈[0.30, 3.00], q 2∈[0.30, 3.00], the uniform design table U10 ∗(108) and its usage table are shown in Table S1 and Table S2. Through the quadratic equation model (1), the functional relationship between q 1, q 2 and Y PC was correlated [37]. The polynomial coefficients are calculated and analyzed by the software Matlab (R2018a). The backward-elimination method in the multiple stepwise regression analysis is used to screen the independent variables that have a significant contribution to the regression equation. The specific process is to introduce all the variables into the regression model. Variables that don't contribute significantly are sequentially eliminated according to the significance level (α remove) until all variables without statistical significance are eliminated. (1) Y = b 0 + ∑ i = 1 2 b i x i + ∑ i = 1 2 b ii x i 2 + ∑ i < j 2 b ij x i x j Where, Y is the response, b 0, b i , b ii , b ij are regression coefficients, x i is the factor, x i 2 is the quadratic effect of the factor, and x i x j is the interaction effect of factors. 2.3 Computational details of molecular simulations In order to verify the effect of solvent basicity on catalytic performance in the cycloaddition, the molecular structure of the solvent (TEA: triethylamine, EtOAc: ethyl acetate, DMF: N,N-Dimethylformamide) was analyzed by computational chemistry. The computational details were as follows: The structure of the solvent molecule is fully optimized at the B3LYP/6–311 + G(d,p) level of theory by the software Gaussian 09W [38], and the electrostatic potential (ESP) is given in the checkpoint file generated during the optimization. 2.4 Evaluation of catalyst performance Experimental procedure for synthesis of PC is showed in the Supplementary material. The conversion of PO (x PO), selectivity (s PC) and yield (Y PC) of PC generated from PO are calculated respectively according to formulas (2)–(4). (2) x PO = m PO ' ‐ m PO m PO ' (3) s PC = m PC × M PO m PO ' ‐ m PO × M PC (4) Y PC = x PO × s PC Where, m PO ' is the mass of PO added to the autoclave, g; m PO is the residual mass of PO after the reaction, g; m PC is the mass of PC produced by the reaction, g; M PC is the relative molecular mass of PC, 102.09 g/mol; M PO is the relative molecular mass of PO, 58.08 g/mol. 3 Results and discussion Starting from the preparation of trimetallic HT-calcined derivatives, the structure-activity relationship between the preparation conditions of catalysts (metal ratio, calcination temperature) and the cycloaddition was studied. The reaction conditions (solvent, catalyst amount, temperature, time, CO2 pressure) were optimized, and the stability of the catalyst was investigated under the best performance. Finally, the catalytic mechanism is proposed based on the experimental results. 3.1 Preparation conditions of the catalysts 3.1.1 Optimization of the metal ratio by uniform design The effect of trimetallic HT-derived oxide with different metal ratios (q 1, q 2) on the catalytic performance of the cycloaddtion was studied by the uniform design method. In No.1–10 of Table 1 , catalysts prepared with different metal ratios have little effect on the x PO, which only fluctuates in the small range of 93.9%–95.5%. According to formula (4), the Y PC is the product of the x PO and s PC. When the x PO fluctuates in a small range, the effects of s PC and Y PC are close to the same. Therefore, the relationship between the response (Y PC) and the independent variable (q 1 and q 2) was fitted by the regression model (1). The regression Eq. (5) was obtained by stepwise regression analysis (backward-elimination method, α remove = 0.01): (5) Y PC = 0.6030 + 0.08388 q 1 + 0.1760 q 2 − 0.01441 q 1 2 − 0.03836 q 2 2 − 0.02464 q 1 q 2 Where, q i is the metal ratio of trimetallic HT-derived oxides, q i 2 is the quadratic effect of the metal ratio and q 1 q 2 is the interaction effect of metal ratio. Comparing the predicted yields (Y PC, Pred) and the experimental yields (Y PC, Exp) in Table 1, its standard deviation is “σ = 0.0030”. Combined with the high determination coefficient (R 2 = 0.993) of eq. (5), the predicted values are in reasonable agreement with the experimental values. Analysis of variance (ANOVA) was used to evaluate the regression model and the results are shown in Table S3. The low error probability of “Prob > F” (P-value = 0.0002 < 0.0500) for the F-value (115.77) indicates that the model eq. (5) is highly significant. The significance test (t-Value) of each variable of regression eq. (5) is shown in Table S4. The t-Value of all variables in eq. (5) have a low error probability of “Prob > |t|” below 0.05, indicating that all variables are significant. In addition, the larger the absolute value of t-Value is, the more significant the influence of the variable on Y PC is. The primary and quadratic terms of q 2 have the largest |t-Value| (|t| = 22.77, 21.71), followed by the |t-Value| (|t| = 13.94) of the interaction term q 1 q 2, and |t-Value| of the primary and secondary terms of q 1 (|t| = 12.03, 8.79) is the smallest, which indicates that the influence of q 2 on Y PC is greater than that of q 1. That is, the influence of Zn in the catalyst on the catalytic activity is higher than that of Mg. The interaction term (q 1 q 2) contributes significantly to eq. (5), indicating that catalysts prepared by complexing multiple metals have strong interactive effects on catalytic activity. The Eq. (5) is represented by the 3D response surface in Fig. 1 , which intuitively indicates that the regression eq. (5) has a maximum yield. The Y PC, Exp of No.1−10 in Table 1 were added to Fig. 1 in the form of scattered points, and it is found that the Y PC, Exp highly matches the response surface predicted by Eq. (5), which illustrates the great validity of Eq. (5). The optimum metal ratio (q 1 ∗=1.31, q 2 ∗=1.87) was calculated from the first and second derivatives of Eq. (5). The predicted optimal yield (Y PC ∗) of the catalyst prepared under the optimum metal ratio reached 82.3%. In order to further verify the validity of Eq. (5), the yield obtained through catalytic experiments was 82.0%, with a relative error of only −0.29%. The reasonable agreement between the predicted and experimental values indicates that the model Eq. (5) can effectively predict the effect of metal ratios (q 1, q 2) on the yield (Y PC). 3.1.2 Optimization of calcination temperature The effects of calcination temperature (100–1250 °C) on the catalytic performance of HT-1.31-1.87 were investigated. In No.11–17 of Table 1, when the calcination temperature is 100–450 °C, the conversion x PO and selectivity s PC both increase; when the calcination temperature exceeds 450 °C, the catalytic activity tends to decrease. Especially, the catalytic activity decreases sharply when the temperature exceeds 650 °C. The reason is that the structures and compositions of catalysts prepared at different calcination temperatures are different, which will be analyzed in the subsequent characterization. Therefore, CHT-1.31-1.87-450 has the best catalytic performance for the cycloaddition of PO and CO2. 3.1.3 Introduction of nucleophiles In Fig. 2 , the x PO is in descending order: KI > KBr > KCl, in which the x PO of KI and KBr are not significantly different and both are close to 100%. The order of the s PC from large to small is also: KI > KBr > KCl, similar to the results from Kim et al. [33] In addition, the order of nucleophilicity of halide ions in the aprotic solvent DMF is [39]: I− < Br− < Cl−, indicating that the catalytic performance weakens with the increase of the nucleophilicity, while too strong nucleophilicity is not conducive to the cycloaddition. Therefore, KI has the best catalytic activity. CHT-1.31-1.87-450 was rehydrated into trimetallic HT through the memory effect, and I− was introduced into the interlayer structure of HT through the exchangeability of HT's anions [30]. The KI-loaded HT-derived oxide was obtained by calcining at 450 °C. The catalytic performance of different KI loadings (2.5%, 5.0%, and 7.5%) on the cycloaddition is shown in No.18–20 of Table 1. Compared with CHT-1.31-1.87-450 (No.13 in Table 1), the introduction of KI can significantly improve the catalytic activity. The x PO and s PC were the highest at 5.0% KI loading and both approached 100%. However, the catalytic activity decreased slightly when the loading amount exceeded 5%. The reason is that too many catalytic sites are provided by excessive nucleophiles, which affects the synergistic catalysis of iodide ions and acid-base sites in the catalyst [29,40]. Therefore, 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450 is the best catalyst for cycloaddition of PO and CO2. 3.2 Optimization of conditions for the cycloaddition 3.2.1 Selection of reaction solvents via molecular simulation Fig. 3 shows the catalytic performance of reaction solvents. The best catalytic performance was obtained with 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450 and DMF as catalyst and solvent, respectively. The x PO and s PC reached 99.9% and 97.9%, respectively. The catalytic performance decreased without solvent, and especially the s PC decreased significantly. The x PO and s PC were <50% when there is only a solvent but no catalyst. Therefore, only when the catalyst is added together with DMF can exhibit ultra-high catalytic activity, which indicates that there is an obvious synergistic catalytic effect between 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450 and DMF. It is generally the acidic-basic sites of the catalytic material that activate the reactants. In order to study the role of the reaction solvent in the catalytic process, the ESP of each solvent was calculated by molecular simulation, and the influence of acidic-basic properties of the solvent on the catalytic performance was explained by catalytic experiments. Color-coded ESP map in Fig. 4 clearly shows the basicity of solvent with different colors: the blue means low electron density (electrophilic regions of positive electrostatic potential, acid sites), the white and yellow indicate neutral energy levels, and the red represents high electron density (nucleophilic region of negative electrostatic potential, basic site). Fig. 4(a) shows that TEA has the minimum electron density, which means that it is the weakest basicity; on the contrary, Fig. 4(c) illustrates that DMF has the maximum electron density, which means that it has the strongest basicity, so the basicity order of solvent is as follows: DMF > EtOAc > TEA. In Fig. 3, regardless of the presence or absence of the catalyst, TEA, EtOAc, and DMF as reaction solvents showed the order of catalytic activity: DMF > EtOAc > TEA. In addition, the comparative plot of the catalytic performance of the three solvents over time in Fig. 5 shows that prolongation of the time increases the conversion and selectivity of the cycloaddition, and shows the same order of catalytic activity as above. Combined with the results of molecular simulation, the order of catalytic activity is consistent with the order of solvent's basicity, indicating that the basicity of the solvent has a strong influence on the catalytic performance of the cycloaddition. The stronger the solvent's basicity, the higher the catalytic performance. 3.2.2 Optimization of conditions: catalyst amount, temperature, time, and CO2 pressure DMF with the strongest basicity was used as the reaction solvent to optimize the conditions of cycloaddition catalyzed by 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450. Fig. 6 (a) shows the catalytic performance of catalyst amounts. When the catalyst amount is <0.5 g, the x PO and s PC increase with the increase of the catalyst amount, and the reason for the low catalytic activity is the insufficient concentration of active sites; when the catalyst amount exceeds 0.5 g, the concentration of active sites is basically saturated, PO is almost completely converted, and the s PC reaches 97.9%. Fig. 6 (b) presents the catalytic performance of temperatures. The x PO increased with the increase of temperature, and PO was nearly completely converted after exceeding 120 °C, which indicated that the increase of temperature could improve the catalytic activity. The s PC reached its maximum (98.7%) at 130 °C, which indicated that the conversion of PO to PC was most favorable at 130 °C, and the side reactions were accelerated when the temperature was lower or higher than 130 °C. Fig. 6 (c) presents the catalytic performance of times. The x PO increased with the reaction time and approached 100% at 8 h. The s PC almost reached the maximum after 8 h, >98%, but decreased slightly after 14 h, which may be due to the synthesis of a small amount of PC oligomers after too long reaction time. Fig. 6 (d) presents the catalytic performance under different initial CO2 pressures. When the initial CO2 pressure is lower than 1.5 MPa, the x PO and s PC increase with the increase of the pressure, which is due to the insufficient concentration of the raw material (CO2). After the initial CO2 pressure reached 1.5 MPa, the x PO and s PC reached 99.5% and 98.6%, respectively, and the catalytic performance remained almost unchanged as the initial CO2 pressure increased. It can be explained that the cycloaddition of PO and CO2 occurred in the liquid phase. In summary, 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450 catalyzed the cycloaddition of PO and CO2 under the conditions of 130 °C and 1.5 MPa initial CO2 pressure for 8 h, and the best performance were obtained: x PO=99.5%, s PC= 98.6%, and Y PC=98.1%. Wang et al. [11] introduced Br into the interlayer structure of MgAl HT and used it to catalyze the cycloaddition of PO and CO2 (reaction conditions: temperature 80 °C, initial CO2 pressure 2 MPa, and time 12 h), the catalytic performance is as follows: x PO=96.3%, s PC=95.5%, and Y PC=92.0%. In contrast, 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450 obtained the x PO and s PC of nearly 100% at a slightly higher reaction temperature, and also reduced the reaction time by a third. 3.2.3 Reusability Fig. 7 shows the results of four repeated experiments with 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450 under the optimal catalytic conditions. The x PO decreased greatly (99.5% to 86.7%), while the s PC decreased slightly (98.6% to 95.9%). The catalyst still maintains high selectivity of PC, and the reason for the obvious decrease of PO conversion is that the catalyst is lost during the recycling process. After the fourth repeated experiment, the catalyst amount decreased by nearly 16% (from 0.50 g to 0.42 g). In order to reduce the influence of the reduction of catalyst amount, the catalytic performance were analyzed from the unit time and unit catalyst amount, such as [x PO/(m cat·t) and s PC/(m cat·t)]. The line graph in Fig. 7 shows that the x PO and s PC are slightly improved under unit time and unit catalyst amount, indicating that 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450 has strong reusability. The product from the first catalytic reaction was analyzed by ICP-MS (Aglient 7800), and the content of I was 9140.8 μg/L (about 9 ppm). The content of Zn, Mg, and Al was obtained by ICP-OES (Aglient 7800) as 9.3 mg/L (about 9 ppm), 7.4 mg/L (about 7 ppm), and 3.9 mg/L (about 4 ppm). The content of active elements in the product was all <10 ppm. Therefore, it shows that 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450 has good stability. 3.3 Characterization of the catalysts 3.3.1 Structure and elemental composition of the catalysts Fig. 8 shows the XRD patterns of CHT-1.31-1.87-z (z = 100–1250 °C) and 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450. In Fig. 8, the diffraction peaks of ZnO appear in all samples (PDF#89–0510). Zheng et al. [41] reported that Zn2+ cannot replace Mg2+ in MgAl HT infinitely to form trimetallic HT, and the excess Zn2+ will form Zn(OH)2 when the Zn/Mg molar ratio is >0.8. The diffraction peaks of zinc hydroxide, zinc carbonate and basic zinc carbonate are not found in Fig. 8. The Zn/Mg molar ratio of the samples in this work was 1.43, so the Zn2+ that did not enter the HT's interlayer structure were converted into ZnO. The samples calcined at 100, 250, 450, and 650 °C have the crystal structure of hydrotalcite (PDF#89–0460), and the diffraction peaks at 11.6°, 23.4°, and 34.8° correspond to the (003), (006), and (012) planes. When the calcination temperature is higher than 450 °C, a weak diffraction peak of MgO crystal phase (PDF#89–7746) appears; when the calcination temperature is higher than 850 °C, the crystal structure of HT has disappeared, and there are obvious diffraction peaks of ZnAl2O4 (PDF#82–1043) and MgO (PDF#89–7746) crystal phases [36]. It is due to the excessive temperature that destroys the HT's layered structure and hydroxides which make up the hydrotalcite's laminates are decomposed, generating single oxides (ZnO and MgO) and spinel-type composite oxides (ZnAl2O4) [42]. The diffraction peak of KI (PDF#89–3621) appeared in 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450. Similar to CHT-1.31-1.87-450, 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450 has a weak diffraction peak of MgO (PDF#89–7746) crystal phase, and still has the HT's structure (PDF#89–0460). HT's derivatives calcined at 100–650 °C have the HT's structure. The d (003) of the (003) crystal plane is the interlayer spacing of the HT's structure, which is obtained by the Bragg eq. (S1); the actual a, b, and c of HT's crystal constant are obtained through the formula (S2). All results are listed in Table 2 . The d (003) of CHT-1.31-1.87-100 is consistent with the CO3 2− intercalated MgAl HT (d (003) = 7.65 Å) [43]. Combined with the interlayer spacing (d (003) = 7.55 Å) of OH− intercalated MgAl HT [43], the decrease of the interlayer spacing with the increase of calcination temperature may be related to the decomposition of CO3 2−. Due to the introduction of KI in 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450, a part of KI is uniformly dispersed in the sample (Fig. 8 shows the crystal phase of KI), and the other part of I− enters the HT's interlayer structure (the d (003) of 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450 is 7.99 Å but the d (003) of CHT-1.31-1.87-450 is 7.56 Å, and d (003) = 8.16 Å corresponds to I− intercalated HT) [43,44]. The crystal constant of HT's structure in Table 2 are close to the standard PDF card: PDF#89–0460 (a = b = 3.05 Å, c = 22.77 Å). The crystalline size D of the different phases in all HT's derivatives was calculated by the full widths at the half maximum of the corresponding peak using the Scherrer's formula (S3), and the results are shown in Table 3 . When the calcination temperature of the samples was >850 °C, D ZnO values changed from the relatively stable and small size (110–130 Å) to larger size (400–600 Å). Similarly, D MgO and D ZnAl2O4 values also increased when the calcination temperature exceeded 850 °C, which was related to the sintering process of HT's derivatives. D HT and D KI values of the samples under low temperature calcination were basically in the size of 100–200 Å, which was almost consistent with the corresponding standard PDF card. In addition, mass fraction W i of the different phases in all HT's derivatives was calculated by formula (S4), and the results are shown in Table 4 . With the increase of calcination temperature, the HT's structure in the samples was decomposed gradually, which leaded to the gradual increase of the W ZnO, W MgO, and W ZnAl2O4 values in the samples. However, the W ZnO value in the samples gradually decreased when the calcination temperature was >850 °C, which was due to ZnO is involved in the formation of ZnAl2O4. The percentage of KI phase in the 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450 indicated that a part of I− entered the interlayer structure of HT (W KI = 1.9% < 5.0%). The SEM topography of CHT-1.31-1.87-450 and 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450 in Fig. 9 illustrated the HT's layered structure, which was consistent with the results of XRD in Fig. 8. Due to the secondary calcination, the layered structure of 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450 was more fragmented than that of CHT-1.31-1.87-450. A separated granular phase (tens of nanometers sized) was found in both CHT-1.31-1.87-450 and 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450 in the SEM images of Fig. 9, and this phase was also observed in the STEM images of Fig. 11. The Zn-mapping in STEM-EDS images of Fig. 11 (b) indicated that this separated phase was rich in “Zn”, which was further inferred to be ZnO phase by XRD diagrams in Fig. 8. Similarly, a small number of linear phase with highlighted part in Mg-mapping was also observed in the middle-upper part of the STEM diagram in Fig. 11 (b), which corresponded to the weak XRD peaks of the MgO phase. The EDS-mapping in Fig. 10 and Fig. 11 showed that the elements Zn, Mg, and Al in CHT-1.31-1.87-450 and 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450 was relatively uniformly dispersed at the scale better than microns. In addition, iodine was also successfully dispersed in 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450. Fig. 12 shows the FT-IR spectra of CHT-1.31-1.87-z (z = 100–1250 °C) and 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450. The absorption peak at 3450 cm−1 and 1635 cm−1 was due to the v OH stretching vibration and the δ OH bending vibration of the hydroxyl group in the HT's layers [36]; the absorption peak at 1380 cm−1 and 854 cm−1 was due to the v CO stretching vibration and the δ CO bending vibration of CO3 2−[36, 42]; the absorption peak at 524 cm−1 was due to the stretching vibration of M-O-Al (M = Zn, Mg), and the absorption peak at 460–400 cm−1 was due to the bending vibration of M-OH-Al [45,46]; the peak at 701 cm−1 corresponded to MgO [47], and the peak at 478 cm−1 corresponded to ZnO [48]. The absorption peaks (1380 cm−1 and 854 cm−1) of CO3 2− almost disappeared when the calcination temperature reached 850 °C, indicating that carbonates in the sample were almost completely decomposed when the calcination temperature was >850 °C, which was consistent with the results of XRD analysis. The relative intensities of the absorption peaks of MgO (701 cm−1) and ZnO (478 cm−1) in 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450 were obviously much larger than those of CHT-1.31-1.87-450. It was explained that 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450 was calcined twice at 450 °C, and formed more MgO and ZnO, which was consistent with the conclusion obtained by XRD analysis in Table 4. The TG-DSC curves of HT-1.31-1.87 shown in Fig. 13 are similar to typical MgAl HT. [49] In the TG curve (red line), a mass loss of 1.77% occurred at 50–150 °C, corresponding to the two endothermic peaks of the DSC curve (blue line): the first endothermic peak (53 °C) was due to the evaporation of physically adsorbed free water; combined with the XRD analysis in Fig. 8, diffraction peaks of ZnO in CHT-1.31-1.87-100 indicated that the second endothermic peak (125 °C) was due to the decomposition of zinc carbonate or zinc hydroxide. The mass loss of 13.42% at 150–195 °C corresponded to the endothermic peak (185 °C), which was due to the evaporation of bound water in the HT's structure [50]. The mass loss of 12.84% and 2.89% occurred at 195–425 °C and 550–680 °C, respectively, corresponding to the endothermic peak (200–625 °C). The analysis in Fig. 8 and Fig. 12 illustrated that CHT-1.31-1.87-650 still contained HT's structure and CO3 2− groups. Combined with the conclusion reported by Yang et al. [50] that the CO3 2− intercalated MgAl HT mainly releases H2O when it is <405 °C, and mainly releases CO2 when it exceeds 405 °C. Therefore, the mass loss of 12.84% was mainly due to the decomposition of OH− groups, and the mass loss of 2.89% was mainly due to the decomposition of CO3 2− groups. A mass loss of 4.17% occurred at 680–920 °C, corresponding to the endothermic peak (825 °C). The analysis for Fig. 8 and Fig. 12 indicated that CHT-1.31-1.87-850 only contained metal oxide (ZnAl2O4, ZnO, and MgO) and didn't contain CO3 2− groups. Therefore, the mass loss of 4.17% mainly was due to the decomposition of all CO3 2− groups and M-OH (M = Zn, Mg, Al) in HT. [49] Table 1 showed the pore structure parameters (specific surface area S BET, pore volume V p, and pore diameter D p) of all catalysts in this work. In Fig. 14 , the 3D scatter plots resulting from No.1–10 of Table 1 illustrated that the maximum of S BET, V p, and D p were mainly concentrated in the range of q 1, q 2∈[1.0, 2.1]. This range of metal ratio corresponds to a high Y PC intuitively in Fig. 1, indicating that within the scope of this research work, the higher the S BET, V p, and D p, the stronger the catalytic performance. The S BET, V p, and D p of the samples calcined at different temperatures in No.11–17 of Table 1 showed a trend of increasing first and then decreasing, and reached the maximum at 250–450 °C. Combined with the analysis of XRD, FT-IR, and TG-DSC, the main reason was that when the calcination temperature was <450 °C, the decomposition of CO3 2− and OH− groups resulted in the formation of numerous pore structures; when the calcination temperature was >450 °C, the original HT's structure collapsed and a close-packed spinel-type metal oxides were generated [36]. The pore structure parameters of catalysts in No.18–20 of Table 1 are almost at the same level, and the small reduction of S BET with the increase of KI loading can be explained that the introduction of KI occupies part of the original pore space. The scatter plots shown in Fig. S2 resulting from No.1–10 of Table 1 indicated that the x PO increased with the increase of S BET, V p, and D p, especially for S BET; The scatter plots shown in Fig. S3 resulting from No.11–17 in Table 1 indicated that the x PO first increased and then remained unchanged with the increase of S BET, V p, and D p, while the s PC also had no obvious regularity. The reason for these phenomena is that the larger S BET provides more active sites for the x PO, but the s PC is mainly determined by the acid-base properties of the catalysts. There were no obvious relationship between the catalytic performance and pore structure parameters in No.18–20 of Table 1. The minor change of catalytic performance can be explained by the synergistic effect between the number of nucleophile active sites and the acid-base sites in the catalysts, which was mainly related to KI loading amount. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (shown in Fig. 15 ) with convex shape at lower relative pressures and hysteresis loop at higher relative pressures were the type IV with the type H3 hysteresis loop in the IUPAC classification, which is consistent with the typical HT. [51] The D p of No.11–17 in Table 1 and the pore size distributions in Fig. 15 are approximately 2–50 nm, indicating that the mesopore is dominant in the HT-calcined derivatives [36]. 3.3.2 Acidic and basic properties of the catalysts In Fig. 16 , the absorption peak around 1450 cm−1 was due to the δ CH bending vibration of pyridine adsorbed on the Lewis acidic site through coordination bonding [52]. The absorption peak at 1540 cm−1 caused by the δ CCN in-plane ring bending vibration of pyridine adsorbed on the Brønsted acidic site wasn't detected in the samples [53], Indicating that there was no strongly Brønsted acidic sites to coordinate with pyridine. The absorption peak caused by hydrogen bonding between the pyridine and the hydroxyl was detected near 1585 cm−1, indicating the existence of weakly Brønsted acidic sites [52,54]. Therefore, the acid types of CHT-1.31-1.87-450 remained unchanged after loading with KI, and both CHT-1.31-1.87-450 and 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450 possessed Brønsted and Lewis acids. The NH3-TPD curve shown in Fig. 17 was deconvoluted into three peaks: the low temperature peak (80–160 °C) corresponded to the weakly Brønsted acidic sites formed by NH3 adsorption, which were attributed to the hydrogen bonding of hydroxyl groups in the samples; the medium temperature peak (160–280 °C) corresponded to the mediumly Lewis acidic sites, which were related to Al3+ in Al3+-O2− groups [52,55]; the high temperature peak (280–420 °C) corresponded to the strongly Lewis acidic sites provided by Zn2+ in Zn2+-O2−, according to the conclusion reported by Cheng et al. [56] that the content of strongly acidic sites increased with the increase of Zn content in Zn-modified MgAl HT. Three adsorbed forms between CO2 and basic sites: bicarbonate, bidentate carbonate, and monodentate carbonate were shown in Fig. S4. Bicarbonate with low binding intensity is generated by CO2 and hydroxyl groups; bidentate carbonate is the combination of CO2 and acid-base pairs (Zn2+-O2−, Mg2+-O2−, or Al3+-O2−), and its intensity is stronger than that of bicarbonate; monodentate carbonate is formed by CO2 and the isolated O2− resulted from the structural edge of single and composite metal oxides, and it has the highest intensity [52]. The CO2-TPD curve shown in Fig. 17 was deconvoluted into three peaks: the low temperature peak (50–130 °C) corresponded to the weakly basic sites of CO2 adsorption, which were related to the formation of bicarbonate [53]; the medium temperature peak (130–220 °C) corresponded to the mediumly basic sites, which were related to the formation of bidentate carbonate [36]; the high temperature peak (220–420 °C) corresponded to the strongly basic sites, which were related to the formation of monodentate carbonate [55]. In Table 5 , compared with CHT-1.31-1.87-450, 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450 had a decrease in the proportion of weakly acidic sites (55.7% to 43.2%), an increase in the proportion of moderately acidic sites (34.6% to 46.9%) and hardly any change in the proportion of strongly acidic sites (9.7% to 9.9%), which was due to the further decomposition of the hydroxyl groups in 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450 by the secondary calcination at 450 °C; similarly, 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450 had almost no change in the proportion of weakly basic sites (54.5% to 53.2%), a slight decrease in the proportion of moderately basic sites (37.7% to 33.6%) and a small increase in the proportion of strongly basic sites (7.8% to 13.2%). The introduction of halogen anions increased the amount of strongly basic sites in the 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450 [57,58]. Total acid and base content of 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450 were less than CHT-1.31-1.87-450, which may be due to the release of H2O from the decomposition of hydroxyl groups. The decrease in the number of hydrogen and oxygen atoms leaded to the reduction of the total acid and base content. In addition, the amount of weak acid and base in the CHT-1.31-1.87-450 and 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450 both accounted for almost half, indicating that most of the acidic and basic sites in the samples were provided by the hydroxyl group. 3.3.3 Catalytic mechanism A possible mechanism of the cycloaddition catalyzed synergistically by 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450 and solvent (DMF) is proposed based on the experimental results. The catalytic process of the cycloaddition between PO and CO2 catalyzed by I− and metal cation at the edge of the HT's layered structure and ZnO phase is shown in Scheme 2 . The specific mechanism is as follows: The O atom in PO was attracted by the weakly Brønsted acidic sites (hydroxyl) existing in the catalyst through hydrogen bonding (I), and then the C atom with the least steric hindrance on the PO ring was attacked by the nucleophile (I−) to open the ring [29,40] (II). A monodentate carbonate was formed through the combination of DMF and CO2 to activate CO2. Simultaneously, the C atom of activated CO2 was attracted by the negatively charged O atom in the PO ring-opening intermediate, and CO2 is inserted to form the carbonate intermediate (III). During the process, a synergistic effect was formed by the Lewis acids (Zn2+, Mg2+, and Al3+) and other active sites, which facilitated the insertion of CO2. Finally, the electrons in the carbonate intermediate were transferred, I− was displaced and the ring was closed to form the cyclic carbonate (PC). The catalyst and solvent enter the next catalytic process. The catalytic process of KI phase is also due to the activation of PO by I− as a nucleophile, which is similar to the mechanism of Scheme 2. 4 Conclusions A HT-calcined composite oxide modified by nucleophile (KI) was developed as a catalyst for the cycloaddition reaction of PO and CO2. Combined with molecular simulation and catalytic experiments, the basicity of the reaction solvent had a positive correlation with the catalytic performance, and DMF was the best solvent. 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450 showed the best catalytic performance under the conditions: T = 130 °C, p CO2 =1.5 MPa, and t = 8 h. the PO conversion and PC selectivity reached 99.5% and 98.6%, respectively, and the catalyst was easy to separate and reuse, and had good stability. The excellent performance of 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450 is jointly determined by the metal ratio, the high specific surface area after calcination at 450 °C, and the strong basic sites induced by nucleophiles. The mechanism of 5.0%KI@CHT-1.31-1.87-450 catalyzing the cycloaddition was proposed: the multifunctional active sites in the catalyst composed of the weakly Brønsted acidic sites provided by hydroxyl groups, Lewis acidic sites provided by metal cation, and nucleophile provided by I−synergistically catalyzed the cycloaddition with the basic sites provided by the solvent DMF. coredata.dc:description: The composition of hydrotalcite-calcined derivatives doped by Zinc was optimized by uniform design. This derivatives further modified by KI nucleophile promoted the catalytic performance in terms of activity, selectivity and stability. N,N-dimethylformamide was proved to be the best solvent for the cycloaddition through molecular simulation. The results of characterization showed that KI-modified derivatives had hydrotalcite phase and ZnO phase, and the elements with catalytic activity were uniformly dispersed. The specific surface area of the derivatives was greatly increased after proper calcination, and it's positively correlated with the cycloaddition activity.The derivatives had acidic-basic properties, and the catalytic mechanism was proposed accordingly.

coredata.dc:title: Hydrotalcite-calcined derivatives doped by zinc: A nucleophile-modified multifunctional catalyst for synthesis of propylene carbonate by cycloaddition
